elements.content: Two novel metal–organic frameworks, namely [Cd3(bdc)­(HCOO)2(tipo)2(H2O)2]·2NO3·6DMF (1) and [Zn8(OH)4(bpdc)6(tipo)4]·16DMF (2) (tipo = tris­[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl]­phosphine oxide, H2bdc = phenyl-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, H2bpdc = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid), have been successfully synthesized. Compound 1 exhibits a cationic 4,6-connected self-catenated framework with large 1D channels. Compound 2 features a 3,4-connected self-catenated framework with potential O donors located on the surface of the channels. Compound 1 shows a high adsorption for dichromate. Postsynthetic modification of 2 by lanthanide ions (Eu3+ and Tb3+) afforded fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text: Two novel metal-organic frameworks, namely [Cd3(bdc)(HCOO)2(tipo)2(H2O)2]⋅2NO3⋅6DMF (1) and [Zn8(OH)4(bpdc)6(tipo)4]⋅16DMF (2) (tipo = tris[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl]phosphine oxide, H2bdc = phenyl-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, H2bpdc = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid), have been successfully synthesized. Compound 1 exhibits a cationic 4,6-connected self-catenated framework with large 1D channels. Compound 2 features a 3,4-connected self-catenated framework with potential O donors located on the surface of the channels. Compound 1 shows a high adsorption for dichromate. Postsynthetic modification of 2 by lanthanide ions (Eu3+ and Tb3+) afforded fluorescent materials.

elements.content: Two novel self-catenated metal−organic frameworks (cnk1 and cnk2) with large accessible channels were obtained by a mixed-ligand strategy from a tripodal N,O-donor ligand. cnk1 shows a high adsorption for dichromate up to 124.4 mg g−1. Postsynthetic modification of cnk2 by lanthanide ions (Eu3+ and Tb3+) afforded fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text: Two novel self-catenated metal-organic frameworks (cnk1 and cnk2) with large accessible channels were obtained by a mixed-ligand strategy from a tripodal N,O-donor ligand. cnk1 shows a high adsorption for dichromate up to 124.4 mg g-1. Postsynthetic modification of cnk2 by lanthanide ions (Eu3+ and Tb3+) afforded fluorescent materials.

elements.content: In the last decades, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have received great attention due to their wide structural diversity and promising application in adsorption, catalysis, luminescence, sensing, biomedicine, energy conversion, electronics, etc. As an emerging class of porous host materials, MOFs enrich versatile host–guest systems. The pore size and surface area of MOFs can be finely tuned by the rational selection of metal ions and design of organic ligands. The adsorption capacity of MOFs for the guests or the stability of host–guest functional materials mainly depends on the interactions between the frameworks and guest molecules in the MOF channels, including hydrogen bonds, π···π stacking interactions, electrostatic forces, and coordination bonds. The adsorption of guests into the porous framework depends on the number and strength of host–guest interactions, and one of the effective strategies to increase them is constructing charged microporous MOFs. Thus, ions of inorganic molecules and organic dyes permeant to the pores can interact more strongly with the frameworks of opposite charge. Furthermore, metal ions can be strongly coordinated on the pore surface to give a new postsynthetically modified MOF with improved properties such as tunable luminescence in the case of lanthanide cations.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the last decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received great attention due to their wide structural diversity and promising application in adsorption, catalysis, luminescence, sensing, biomedicine, energy conversion, electronics, etc. As an emerging class of porous host materials, MOFs enrich versatile host-guest systems. The pore size and surface area of MOFs can be finely tuned by the rational selection of metal ions and design of organic ligands. The adsorption capacity of MOFs for the guests or the stability of host-guest functional materials mainly depends on the interactions between the frameworks and guest molecules in the MOF channels, including hydrogen bonds, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions, electrostatic forces, and coordination bonds. The adsorption of guests into the porous framework depends on the number and strength of host-guest interactions, and one of the effective strategies to increase them is constructing charged microporous MOFs. Thus, ions of inorganic molecules and organic dyes permeant to the pores can interact more strongly with the frameworks of opposite charge. Furthermore, metal ions can be strongly coordinated on the pore surface to give a new postsynthetically modified MOF with improved properties such as tunable luminescence in the case of lanthanide cations.

elements.content: In this work, we synthesized a new tripodal ligand, tris­[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)]­phosphine oxide (tipo), as the building unit (). Similar to N-centered analogues, such a ligand of triangular shape, medium flexibility, and long spacing can give highly porous and robust frameworks. However, the same construction features are also beneficial for entangled motifs, and combinations of porosity and entanglements are very rare cases. Moreover, the PO group can coordinate a metal ion to expand the network connectivity or to provide a potential adsorption site. Successfully, the mixed-ligand strategy resulted in two MOFs with unusual patterns of self-catenation: namely, [Cd3(bdc)­(HCOO)2(tipo)2(H2O)2]·2NO3·6DMF (1) and [Zn8(OH)4(bpdc)6(tipo)4]·16DMF (2). Compound 1 is stable in water and shows highly efficient Cr2O7 2– removal from aqueous solution for the cationic framework properties. Postsynthetic modification of 2 with Eu3+ and Tb3+ afforded fluorescent lanthanide­(III)-loaded materials.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we synthesized a new tripodal ligand, tris[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)]phosphine oxide (tipo), as the building unit (). Similar to N-centered analogues, such a ligand of triangular shape, medium flexibility, and long spacing can give highly porous and robust frameworks. However, the same construction features are also beneficial for entangled motifs, and combinations of porosity and entanglements are very rare cases. Moreover, the PO group can coordinate a metal ion to expand the network connectivity or to provide a potential adsorption site. Successfully, the mixed-ligand strategy resulted in two MOFs with unusual patterns of self-catenation: namely, [Cd3(bdc)(HCOO)2(tipo)2(H2O)2]⋅2NO3⋅6DMF (1) and [Zn8(OH)4(bpdc)6(tipo)4]⋅16DMF (2). Compound 1 is stable in water and shows highly efficient Cr2O7 2- removal from aqueous solution for the cationic framework properties. Postsynthetic modification of 2 with Eu3+ and Tb3+ afforded fluorescent lanthanide(III)-loaded materials.

elements.clean_text: 1  Ligands Used in Synthesis of the Two MOFs

elements.content: The ligand tipo was synthesized according to our reported method. All of the other starting materials were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer 580B IR spectrometer in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. TGA was performed on a PerkinElmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 30 to 800 °C under nitrogen (Figure S5). The luminescent properties of these compounds were measured on a Hitachi F7000 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D2 Phaser instrument. UV–vis adsorption spectra were collected on a Shimadzu UV-3101PC spectrophotometer to monitor the ion-exchange progress.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

The ligand tipo was synthesized according to our reported method. All of the other starting materials were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer 580B IR spectrometer in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. TGA was performed on a PerkinElmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 30 to 800 °C under nitrogen (Figure S5). The luminescent properties of these compounds were measured on a Hitachi F7000 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D2 Phaser instrument. UV-vis adsorption spectra were collected on a Shimadzu UV-3101PC spectrophotometer to monitor the ion-exchange progress.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0616 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (0.0166 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL),and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.5 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 50% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C80H94Cd3N20O24P2: C, 45.34; H, 4.47; N, 13.22. Found: C, 45.45; H, 4.55; N, 13.30.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.0616 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (0.0166 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL),and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.5 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 50% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C80H94Cd3N20O24P2: C, 45.34; H, 4.47; N, 13.22. Found: C, 45.45; H, 4.55; N, 13.30.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0298 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bpdc (0.0242 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.2 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 70% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C240H248N40O48P4Zn8: C, 56.43; H, 4.89; N, 10.97. Found: C, 56.54; H, 4.81; N, 10.85.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0298 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bpdc (0.0242 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.2 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 70% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C240H248N40O48P4Zn8: C, 56.43; H, 4.89; N, 10.97. Found: C, 56.54; H, 4.81; N, 10.85.

elements.content: A 30 mg portion of 2 was immersed in a DMF solution of nitrate salts of Eu3+ and Tb3+ (5 mL, 1 mmol) at 60 °C for 2 days. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol several times to remove the residual Ln3+, and dried at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ln3+@2 (Ln = Eu, Tb)

A 30 mg portion of 2 was immersed in a DMF solution of nitrate salts of Eu3+ and Tb3+ (5 mL, 1 mmol) at 60 °C for 2 days. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol several times to remove the residual Ln3+, and dried at room temperature.

elements.content: The adsorption isotherms and relevant parameters can be obtained by fitting against the Langmuir isotherm model: Q e = Q m C e / ( 1 + K s C e ) where C e is the equilibrium solution concentration (mg/L), Q e (mg/g) is the adsorption amount at different equilibrium solute concentration, Q m is the Langmuir maximum adsorption capacity (mg/g) and K s is the Langmuir adsorption constant.
elements.clean_text:
Cr2O7 2- Maximum Adsorption Study

The adsorption isotherms and relevant parameters can be obtained by fitting against the Langmuir isotherm model:      Q   e   =   Q   m     C   e   /  ( 1 +   K   s     C   e   )    where C e is the equilibrium solution concentration (mg/L), Q e (mg/g) is the adsorption amount at different equilibrium solute concentration, Q m is the Langmuir maximum adsorption capacity (mg/g) and K s is the Langmuir adsorption constant.

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD data for 1 and 2 were recorded on a Bruker Smart Apex II diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 120(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied using the multiscan technique. The structures of these two compounds were solved with SHELXT and refined with SHELXL. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms were fixed to appropriate distances and refined from the electron density map. For disordered solvent molecules in the structure, PLATON/SQUEEZE was applied to remove their diffraction contribution. Thus, there were “Alert level A” about “Check Reported Molecular Weight” and “VERY LARGE Solvent Accessible VOID­(S) in Structure” in the “checkCIF/PLATON report” files for 1 and 2. Meanwhile, the check-cif report for 1 and 2 also reflected a “B” level alert about “D-H Without Acceptor” because it was unable to define the hydrogen bonds for the removal of disordered solvent molecules. The final formulas of 1 and 2 were derived from crystallographic data combined with elemental and TGA analysis data. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal XRD data for 1 and 2 were recorded on a Bruker Smart Apex II diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 120(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied using the multiscan technique. The structures of these two compounds were solved with SHELXT and refined with SHELXL. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms were fixed to appropriate distances and refined from the electron density map. For disordered solvent molecules in the structure, PLATON/SQUEEZE was applied to remove their diffraction contribution. Thus, there were "Alert level A" about "Check Reported Molecular Weight" and "VERY LARGE Solvent Accessible VOID(S) in Structure" in the "checkCIF/PLATON report" files for 1 and 2. Meanwhile, the check-cif report for 1 and 2 also reflected a "B" level alert about "D-H Without Acceptor" because it was unable to define the hydrogen bonds for the removal of disordered solvent molecules. The final formulas of 1 and 2 were derived from crystallographic data combined with elemental and TGA analysis data. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in .

Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of two Cd2+ cations, one tipo ligand, one formate anion, and half of bdc2–. The formate anion was generated through the hydrolysis of DMF molecules under solvothermal conditions. As shown in a, Cd1 is coordinated by four N atoms from four tipo ligands and two O atoms from two formate anions. Cd2 is ligated by one N atom from one tipo and five O atoms from one bdc2– anion, one tipo ligand, and one formate anion. Cd2+ to O/N bond distances and valence angles are within the normal range (Table S1). The formate anion coordinates two Cd2+ cations in a syn,syn,anti mode. The bdc2– ligand connects two Cd2+ cations by two chelate carboxylates. The tipo ligand coordinates four Cd2+ in quadridentate mode, forming bonds N2–Cd1A, N6–Cd1B, N4–Cd1A, and O1–Cd2B.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Characterization of 1 

Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of two Cd2+ cations, one tipo ligand, one formate anion, and half of bdc2-. The formate anion was generated through the hydrolysis of DMF molecules under solvothermal conditions. As shown in a, Cd1 is coordinated by four N atoms from four tipo ligands and two O atoms from two formate anions. Cd2 is ligated by one N atom from one tipo and five O atoms from one bdc2- anion, one tipo ligand, and one formate anion. Cd2+ to O/N bond distances and valence angles are within the normal range (Table S1). The formate anion coordinates two Cd2+ cations in a syn,syn,anti mode. The bdc2- ligand connects two Cd2+ cations by two chelate carboxylates. The tipo ligand coordinates four Cd2+ in quadridentate mode, forming bonds N2-Cd1A, N6-Cd1B, N4-Cd1A, and O1-Cd2B.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Cd2+ atoms in 1. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) View of the penetration of the 4-ring {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N′)2} by the bdc2– linker. (c) Underlying net in compound 1. The edges presenting linkers HCOO– and bdc2– arms are highlighted by blue and dark red, respectively. The edges corresponded to tipo arms and highlighting different Cd-tipo sublayers are shown in green, yellow, and purple. (d) The 1D channels along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Cd2+ atoms in 1. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) View of the penetration of the 4-ring {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N')2} by the bdc2- linker. (c) Underlying net in compound 1. The edges presenting linkers HCOO- and bdc2- arms are highlighted by blue and dark red, respectively. The edges corresponded to tipo arms and highlighting different Cd-tipo sublayers are shown in green, yellow, and purple. (d) The 1D channels along the a axis.

elements.content: Within the structure, the bdc2– linker penetrates the ring {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N′)2} (b). The short HCOO– anions stitch the neighboring Cd–tipo layers, and the long bdc2– anions bind two alternating layers separated by one intermediate layer. The three arms of tipo ligands are aligned along the arms of three other tipo ligands; they participate in π–π stacking and formation of rings {(Cd2)2(tipo-O,N)2} and {(Cd2)2(HCOO)2(tipo-O,N)2} (Figure S1). From a topological point of view, the underlying net of the compound 1 in the standard representation of ToposPro package contains 4-coordinated nodes of tipo and Cd2 and 6-coordinated nodes of Cd1 (c). The resulting 4,6-coordinated 3D net belongs to a new topological type with point symbol (4·5·62·72)2(42·54·64·73·92)­(42·64)2. We gave the name cnk1 to the net, which was added to the TTD database of program package ToposPro (https://topcryst.com/). cnk1 contains nine symmetrically and topologically different strong rings of minimal sizes 4 (4a, 4b), 5 (5a), 6 (6a, 6b, 6c, 6d), and 10 (10a, 10b). We found that the cnk1 net is self-catenated, since the three rings 4b, 10a, and 10b catenate each other to form bouquets of 4, 6, and 6 rings, respectively (Table S2). Thus, the pattern of ring catenations can be described by a 4,6-coordinated 3D Hopf ring net with point symbol (44·610·8)2(64·82). The catenation is a result of only penetration of the 4-ring by an edge, which corresponded to the {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N′)2} ring and bdc2– linker, respectively (b). Therefore, a subnet (topological type 3,4,6T53) constructed only by formate and tipo linkers with Cd2+ does not contain catenations of rings. The tipo ligand with Cd2+ constructs a 3,4-coordinated 2D subnet of the well-known topology bex (highlighted by green, yellow, and purple in c). Calculation in Platon shows 44.7% of solvent-accessible porosity. Moreover, the largest 1D channel spreading along the a axis has the minimal radius R f(1D) = 3.6 Å (d). From our experience, we know only three isostructural families of other self-catenated frameworks with wider channels (in the standard representation of ToposPro) (Table S3).
elements.clean_text: Within the structure, the bdc2- linker penetrates the ring {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N')2} (b). The short HCOO- anions stitch the neighboring Cd-tipo layers, and the long bdc2- anions bind two alternating layers separated by one intermediate layer. The three arms of tipo ligands are aligned along the arms of three other tipo ligands; they participate in π-π stacking and formation of rings {(Cd2)2(tipo-O,N)2} and {(Cd2)2(HCOO)2(tipo-O,N)2} (Figure S1). From a topological point of view, the underlying net of the compound 1 in the standard representation of ToposPro package contains 4-coordinated nodes of tipo and Cd2 and 6-coordinated nodes of Cd1 (c). The resulting 4,6-coordinated 3D net belongs to a new topological type with point symbol (4⋅5⋅62⋅72)2(42⋅54⋅64⋅73⋅92)(42⋅64)2. We gave the name cnk1 to the net, which was added to the TTD database of program package ToposPro (https://topcryst.com/). cnk1 contains nine symmetrically and topologically different strong rings of minimal sizes 4 (4a, 4b), 5 (5a), 6 (6a, 6b, 6c, 6d), and 10 (10a, 10b). We found that the cnk1 net is self-catenated, since the three rings 4b, 10a, and 10b catenate each other to form bouquets of 4, 6, and 6 rings, respectively (Table S2). Thus, the pattern of ring catenations can be described by a 4,6-coordinated 3D Hopf ring net with point symbol (44⋅610⋅8)2(64⋅82). The catenation is a result of only penetration of the 4-ring by an edge, which corresponded to the {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N')2} ring and bdc2- linker, respectively (b). Therefore, a subnet (topological type 3,4,6T53) constructed only by formate and tipo linkers with Cd2+ does not contain catenations of rings. The tipo ligand with Cd2+ constructs a 3,4-coordinated 2D subnet of the well-known topology bex (highlighted by green, yellow, and purple in c). Calculation in Platon shows 44.7% of solvent-accessible porosity. Moreover, the largest 1D channel spreading along the a axis has the minimal radius R f(1D) = 3.6 Å (d). From our experience, we know only three isostructural families of other self-catenated frameworks with wider channels (in the standard representation of ToposPro) (Table S3).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. In the structure, there are four crystallographically unique Zn2+ cations, four bpdc2– anions, two tipo ligands, and two OH– groups. As shown in a, all of the Zn2+ cations adopt a distorted-tetrahedral geometry. Zn1 and Zn4 are both coordinated by one N atom from one tipo ligand and three O atoms from one OH– group and two bpdc2– anions. Zn2 and Zn3 are both coordinated by two N atoms from two tipo ligands and two O atoms from one OH– group and one bpdc2– anion. Zn2+ to O/N bond distances and valence angles are within the normal range (Table S4). All bpdc2– anions connect two Zn2+ atoms by two monodentate carboxylates. Both tipo ligands coordinate three Zn2+ cations by three N atoms, leaving the oxygen donor atom of the PO group unreacted. Zn1 and Zn2 are combined by one μ2-bridging OH– group to build a {Zn2O} dimer. The same is true for Zn3 and Zn4. Within the structure, the {Zn2O} dimers are connected by bpdc2– anions to give rise to a 3-coordinated 2D hcb subnet (b). The tipo liands join the {Zn2O} dimers to generate 1D 3-coordinated subnets of topology (4,4)­(0,2) (c). These two nets are interconnected into the new 3,6-coordinated net with the point symbol (42·610·83)­(42·6), in which the {Zn2O} dimers are considered as the 6-coordinated nodes and the tipo ligands are simplified as the 3-coordinated nodes (d,e). However, the underlying net in standard representation is 3,4-coordinated with point symbol (4·6·83·10)­(4·6·8)­(6·84·10) (Figure S2), and we added it to the ToposPro topological collection under the new name cnk2 (https://topcryst.com/).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization of 2 

Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. In the structure, there are four crystallographically unique Zn2+ cations, four bpdc2- anions, two tipo ligands, and two OH- groups. As shown in a, all of the Zn2+ cations adopt a distorted-tetrahedral geometry. Zn1 and Zn4 are both coordinated by one N atom from one tipo ligand and three O atoms from one OH- group and two bpdc2- anions. Zn2 and Zn3 are both coordinated by two N atoms from two tipo ligands and two O atoms from one OH- group and one bpdc2- anion. Zn2+ to O/N bond distances and valence angles are within the normal range (Table S4). All bpdc2- anions connect two Zn2+ atoms by two monodentate carboxylates. Both tipo ligands coordinate three Zn2+ cations by three N atoms, leaving the oxygen donor atom of the PO group unreacted. Zn1 and Zn2 are combined by one μ2-bridging OH- group to build a {Zn2O} dimer. The same is true for Zn3 and Zn4. Within the structure, the {Zn2O} dimers are connected by bpdc2- anions to give rise to a 3-coordinated 2D hcb subnet (b). The tipo liands join the {Zn2O} dimers to generate 1D 3-coordinated subnets of topology (4,4)(0,2) (c). These two nets are interconnected into the new 3,6-coordinated net with the point symbol (42⋅610⋅83)(42⋅6), in which the {Zn2O} dimers are considered as the 6-coordinated nodes and the tipo ligands are simplified as the 3-coordinated nodes (d,e). However, the underlying net in standard representation is 3,4-coordinated with point symbol (4⋅6⋅83⋅10)(4⋅6⋅8)(6⋅84⋅10) (Figure S2), and we added it to the ToposPro topological collection under the new name cnk2 (https://topcryst.com/).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ cations in 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Perspective view of 3-coordinated 2D hcb subnets generated by the {Zn2O} dimers and bpdc2– anions. (c) Perspective view of 1D 3-coordinated subnets constructed by the {Zn2O} dimers and tipo liands. (d) Perspective view of framework of 2 (the uncoordinated PO marked by green). (e) Corresponding 3,6-coordinated underlying net. (f) Schematic view of the self-catenation in 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ cations in 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Perspective view of 3-coordinated 2D hcb subnets generated by the {Zn2O} dimers and bpdc2- anions. (c) Perspective view of 1D 3-coordinated subnets constructed by the {Zn2O} dimers and tipo liands. (d) Perspective view of framework of 2 (the uncoordinated PO marked by green). (e) Corresponding 3,6-coordinated underlying net. (f) Schematic view of the self-catenation in 2.

elements.content: Further, the 4-rings of subnet (4,4)­(0,2) are penetrated by edges of bpdc2–, and the 6-rings of subnet hcb are penetrated by arms of tipo (f). Together these penetrations produce a very complicated 3D self-catenation with the participation of 78 different rings, and the number of catenations of one ring with others varies from 16 to 140 (Table S5). There is a 2D system of channels in the (100) crystallographic plane with minimal radius R f(2D) = 1.67 Å, maximum radius R i = 3.2 Å, and 32.9% of unit cell volume. The widest channel with R f(1D) = 1.7 Å spreads along the b axis (d). The total void space accounts for approximately 37.5% of the whole crystal volume as obtained by PLATON analysis. Interestingly, the uncoordinated PO groups of tipo point into the channels, which can act as the potential coordinative moiety for lanthanide ions.
elements.clean_text: Further, the 4-rings of subnet (4,4)(0,2) are penetrated by edges of bpdc2-, and the 6-rings of subnet hcb are penetrated by arms of tipo (f). Together these penetrations produce a very complicated 3D self-catenation with the participation of 78 different rings, and the number of catenations of one ring with others varies from 16 to 140 (Table S5). There is a 2D system of channels in the (100) crystallographic plane with minimal radius R f(2D) = 1.67 Å, maximum radius R i = 3.2 Å, and 32.9% of unit cell volume. The widest channel with R f(1D) = 1.7 Å spreads along the b axis (d). The total void space accounts for approximately 37.5% of the whole crystal volume as obtained by PLATON analysis. Interestingly, the uncoordinated PO groups of tipo point into the channels, which can act as the potential coordinative moiety for lanthanide ions.

elements.content: Inspired by the high pore volume and cationic framework of compound 1 determined from structural studies, we decided to explore its potential for application in Cr2O7 2– adsorption. For this 10 mg of 1 was immersed in 15 mL of a K2Cr2O7 aqueous solution (50 mg L–1), respectively. The clear solution after centrifuging was measured by UV/vis spectra at 350 nm to monitor the Cr2O7 2– concentration at different time intervals. As shown in a, the r2O7 2– concentration decreased quickly to 43% in 1 min. In about 120 min, over 78% of the Cr2O7 2– can be removed from the aqueous solution. The result indicates that the Cr2O7 2– in solution promptly entered into the channels in 1 by exchanging NO3 –, which can be confirmed by IR spectra by the disappearance of the broad band arising from NO3 – at 1380 cm–1 (Figure S7). To further evaluate the adsorption maximum of 1 toward Cr2O7 2–, different concentrations of Cr2O7 2– solution in the range of 50–700 mg L–1 were used to determine the uptake. As shown in b, the overall adsorption capacity of 1 for Cr2O7 2– reaches up to 124.4 mg g–1, which ranks among the highest Cr2O7 2– adsorption in MOF materials ever reported. In addition, the Langmuir isotherm has been applied to evaluate the maximum adsorption capacity with a correlation coefficient of 0.9838 (b). Accordingly, the calculated maximum adsorption capacity of 1 for Cr2O7 2– is 128.3 mg g–1, which is approximately the experimental value. Meanwhile, release tests were also carried out to evaluate the regeneration ability of the ion exchanger. The release efficiency of Cr2O7 2– was high: up to 92% after immersion of Cr2O7 2–@1 in a saturated KNO3 solution over 120 min (Figure S6). Further, the PXRD of compound 1 immersed in water after 2 days shows that the framework does not collapse and shows good water stability. It should be noted that, after the release of Cr2O7 2–, although some peaks in the PXRD were weakened, the framework still keeps its integrity (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Capability of 1 toward Cr2O7 2- 

Inspired by the high pore volume and cationic framework of compound 1 determined from structural studies, we decided to explore its potential for application in Cr2O7 2- adsorption. For this 10 mg of 1 was immersed in 15 mL of a K2Cr2O7 aqueous solution (50 mg L-1), respectively. The clear solution after centrifuging was measured by UV/vis spectra at 350 nm to monitor the Cr2O7 2- concentration at different time intervals. As shown in a, the r2O7 2- concentration decreased quickly to 43% in 1 min. In about 120 min, over 78% of the Cr2O7 2- can be removed from the aqueous solution. The result indicates that the Cr2O7 2- in solution promptly entered into the channels in 1 by exchanging NO3 -, which can be confirmed by IR spectra by the disappearance of the broad band arising from NO3 - at 1380 cm-1 (Figure S7). To further evaluate the adsorption maximum of 1 toward Cr2O7 2-, different concentrations of Cr2O7 2- solution in the range of 50-700 mg L-1 were used to determine the uptake. As shown in b, the overall adsorption capacity of 1 for Cr2O7 2- reaches up to 124.4 mg g-1, which ranks among the highest Cr2O7 2- adsorption in MOF materials ever reported. In addition, the Langmuir isotherm has been applied to evaluate the maximum adsorption capacity with a correlation coefficient of 0.9838 (b). Accordingly, the calculated maximum adsorption capacity of 1 for Cr2O7 2- is 128.3 mg g-1, which is approximately the experimental value. Meanwhile, release tests were also carried out to evaluate the regeneration ability of the ion exchanger. The release efficiency of Cr2O7 2- was high: up to 92% after immersion of Cr2O7 2-@1 in a saturated KNO3 solution over 120 min (Figure S6). Further, the PXRD of compound 1 immersed in water after 2 days shows that the framework does not collapse and shows good water stability. It should be noted that, after the release of Cr2O7 2-, although some peaks in the PXRD were weakened, the framework still keeps its integrity (Figure S3).

elements.content: (a) Plots of UV/vis spectra for 15 mL of a K2Cr2O7 aqueous solution (50 mg L–1) after addition of 10 mg of compound 1 and further centrifugation to monitor the Cr2O7 2– concentration at different time intervals. (b) Langmuir isotherm to evaluate the maximum adsorption capacity with a correlation coefficient of 0.9838.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Plots of UV/vis spectra for 15 mL of a K2Cr2O7 aqueous solution (50 mg L-1) after addition of 10 mg of compound 1 and further centrifugation to monitor the Cr2O7 2- concentration at different time intervals. (b) Langmuir isotherm to evaluate the maximum adsorption capacity with a correlation coefficient of 0.9838.

elements.content: As was elucidated from the structural analysis, the presence of an uncoordinated PO group protruding into the channels of compound 2 gave us an opportunity to study cation adsorption and the corresponding structure modification abilities of the framework. Thus, we have discovered the good affinity of a PO group for lanthanide cations. Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions have been introduced into the 1D channels of 2 by soaking the samples in DMF solutions of their nitrate salts. The loading of Ln3+ does not influence the crystal structure integrity of 2, as demonstrated by PXRD profiles (Figure S4). When the FT-IR spectra of 2 and Eu3+@2 are compared, the characteristic absorbance of NO3 – (1350 cm–1) in Eu3+@2 indicates the introduction of Eu­(NO3)3 into the channels (Figure S8). Upon excitation at 333 nm, Eu3+@2 displays narrow luminescence originating from the Eu­(III) lowest emitting state 5D0 to 7F0 (578 nm), 7F1 (591 nm), 7F2 (615 nm), 7F3 (650 nm) ,and 7F4 (695 nm) levels (a). The most intense peak at 615 nm corresponds to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition, yielding an intense red color emission. On excitation at 254 nm under UV light, Eu3+@2 showed a bright red light, which can be easily observed by the naked eye, as shown in the inset of a. Moreover, Eu3+@2 exhibits a long emission lifetime (1.07 ms), further demonstrating that the MOF 2 can serve as an efficient scaffold for hosting and sensitizing Eu3+ (a). For Tb3+@2, on excitation at 337 nm, the emission lines are located at about 488, 542, 582, and 616 nm, which can be assigned to 5D4 → 7F J (J = 6, 5, 4, 3) transitions of Tb3+ (b). For Eu3+@2, the emission of 2 is hardly detected, suggesting efficient energy transfer between the ligand and Eu3+. However, for Tb3+@2, the ligand-centered emission band located at about 428 nm is obvious, which means that the energy transfer between the ligand and Tb3+ is not as strong as that between the ligand and Eu3+ (b).
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties of Ln3+@2 (Ln3+ = Eu3+, Tb3+)

As was elucidated from the structural analysis, the presence of an uncoordinated PO group protruding into the channels of compound 2 gave us an opportunity to study cation adsorption and the corresponding structure modification abilities of the framework. Thus, we have discovered the good affinity of a PO group for lanthanide cations. Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions have been introduced into the 1D channels of 2 by soaking the samples in DMF solutions of their nitrate salts. The loading of Ln3+ does not influence the crystal structure integrity of 2, as demonstrated by PXRD profiles (Figure S4). When the FT-IR spectra of 2 and Eu3+@2 are compared, the characteristic absorbance of NO3 - (1350 cm-1) in Eu3+@2 indicates the introduction of Eu(NO3)3 into the channels (Figure S8). Upon excitation at 333 nm, Eu3+@2 displays narrow luminescence originating from the Eu(III) lowest emitting state 5D0 to 7F0 (578 nm), 7F1 (591 nm), 7F2 (615 nm), 7F3 (650 nm) ,and 7F4 (695 nm) levels (a). The most intense peak at 615 nm corresponds to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition, yielding an intense red color emission. On excitation at 254 nm under UV light, Eu3+@2 showed a bright red light, which can be easily observed by the naked eye, as shown in the inset of a. Moreover, Eu3+@2 exhibits a long emission lifetime (1.07 ms), further demonstrating that the MOF 2 can serve as an efficient scaffold for hosting and sensitizing Eu3+ (a). For Tb3+@2, on excitation at 337 nm, the emission lines are located at about 488, 542, 582, and 616 nm, which can be assigned to 5D4 → 7F J  (J = 6, 5, 4, 3) transitions of Tb3+ (b). For Eu3+@2, the emission of 2 is hardly detected, suggesting efficient energy transfer between the ligand and Eu3+. However, for Tb3+@2, the ligand-centered emission band located at about 428 nm is obvious, which means that the energy transfer between the ligand and Tb3+ is not as strong as that between the ligand and Eu3+ (b).

elements.content: (a) Room-temperature excitation (black) and emission (red) spectra of Eu3+@2. (b) Room-temperature excitation (black) and emission (green) spectra of Tb3+@2.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Room-temperature excitation (black) and emission (red) spectra of Eu3+@2. (b) Room-temperature excitation (black) and emission (green) spectra of Tb3+@2.

elements.content: (a) Experimental (black) and calculated (red) luminescence decay plots for Eu3+@2 for a peak at 616 nm after excitation at 333 nm. (b) Experimental (black) and calculated (green) luminescence decay plots for Tb3+@2 for a peak at 582 nm after excitation at 337 nm.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Experimental (black) and calculated (red) luminescence decay plots for Eu3+@2 for a peak at 616 nm after excitation at 333 nm. (b) Experimental (black) and calculated (green) luminescence decay plots for Tb3+@2 for a peak at 582 nm after excitation at 337 nm.

elements.content: In this work, using a tripodal phosphine oxide centered ligand in a mix with dicarboxylate ligands and d-metal cations, we successfully assembled two novel self-catenated metal–organic frameworks. Compound 1 exhibits a cationic 4,6-connected self-penetrating framework with large 1D channels, which shows a high adsorption for dichromate up to 124.4 mg g–1. Compound 2 features a 3,4-connected self-catenated framework with potential O-donors located on the surface of the channels. Postsynthetic modification of 2 by lanthanide ions (Eu3+ and Tb3+) afforded fluorescent materials. The results show that tris­[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)]­phosphine oxide can act as a 3- or 4-coordinated N,O-donor ligand. Such interesting coordination behaviors inspired us to focus on the structures and properties of more MOFs constructed from tipo with versatile polycarboxylate ligands and metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, using a tripodal phosphine oxide centered ligand in a mix with dicarboxylate ligands and d-metal cations, we successfully assembled two novel self-catenated metal-organic frameworks. Compound 1 exhibits a cationic 4,6-connected self-penetrating framework with large 1D channels, which shows a high adsorption for dichromate up to 124.4 mg g-1. Compound 2 features a 3,4-connected self-catenated framework with potential O-donors located on the surface of the channels. Postsynthetic modification of 2 by lanthanide ions (Eu3+ and Tb3+) afforded fluorescent materials. The results show that tris[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)]phosphine oxide can act as a 3- or 4-coordinated N,O-donor ligand. Such interesting coordination behaviors inspired us to focus on the structures and properties of more MOFs constructed from tipo with versatile polycarboxylate ligands and metal ions.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0616 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (0.0166 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL),and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.5 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 50% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C80H94Cd3N20O24P2: C, 45.34; H, 4.47; N, 13.22. Found: C, 45.45; H, 4.55; N, 13.30.

Synthesis of <bold>2</bold>

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0298 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bpdc (0.0242 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.2 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 70% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C240H248N40O48P4Zn8: C, 56.43; H, 4.89; N, 10.97. Found: C, 56.54; H, 4.81; N, 10.85.

Synthesis of Ln<sup>3+</sup>@<bold>2</bold> (Ln = Eu, Tb)

A 30 mg portion of 2 was immersed in a DMF solution of nitrate salts of Eu3+ and Tb3+ (5 mL, 1 mmol) at 60 °C for 2 days. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol several times to remove the residual Ln3+, and dried at room temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.0616 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (0.0166 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL),and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.5 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 50% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C80H94Cd3N20O24P2: C, 45.34; H, 4.47; N, 13.22. Found: C, 45.45; H, 4.55; N, 13.30.

Synthesis of 2 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0298 g, 0.2 mmol), tipo (0.0476 g, 0.1 mmol), H2bpdc (0.0242 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (8 mL), methanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (1 mL, 0.2 M) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20 mL), heated at 80 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried. Yields: 70% (based on tipo). Anal. Calcd for C240H248N40O48P4Zn8: C, 56.43; H, 4.89; N, 10.97. Found: C, 56.54; H, 4.81; N, 10.85.

Synthesis of Ln3+@2 (Ln = Eu, Tb)

A 30 mg portion of 2 was immersed in a DMF solution of nitrate salts of Eu3+ and Tb3+ (5 mL, 1 mmol) at 60 °C for 2 days. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol several times to remove the residual Ln3+, and dried at room temperature.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Ligands Used in Synthesis of the Two MOFs

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Cd2+ atoms in 1. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) View of the penetration of the 4-ring {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N′)2} by the bdc2– linker. (c) Underlying net in compound 1. The edges presenting linkers HCOO– and bdc2– arms are highlighted by blue and dark red, respectively. The edges corresponded to tipo arms and highlighting different Cd-tipo sublayers are shown in green, yellow, and purple. (d) The 1D channels along the a axis.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Cd2+ atoms in 1. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) View of the penetration of the 4-ring {(Cd1)2(tipo-N,N')2} by the bdc2- linker. (c) Underlying net in compound 1. The edges presenting linkers HCOO- and bdc2- arms are highlighted by blue and dark red, respectively. The edges corresponded to tipo arms and highlighting different Cd-tipo sublayers are shown in green, yellow, and purple. (d) The 1D channels along the a axis.

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ cations in 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Perspective view of 3-coordinated 2D hcb subnets generated by the {Zn2O} dimers and bpdc2– anions. (c) Perspective view of 1D 3-coordinated subnets constructed by the {Zn2O} dimers and tipo liands. (d) Perspective view of framework of 2 (the uncoordinated PO marked by green). (e) Corresponding 3,6-coordinated underlying net. (f) Schematic view of the self-catenation in 2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ cations in 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Perspective view of 3-coordinated 2D hcb subnets generated by the {Zn2O} dimers and bpdc2- anions. (c) Perspective view of 1D 3-coordinated subnets constructed by the {Zn2O} dimers and tipo liands. (d) Perspective view of framework of 2 (the uncoordinated PO marked by green). (e) Corresponding 3,6-coordinated underlying net. (f) Schematic view of the self-catenation in 2.

cln_elements.content: (a) Plots of UV/vis spectra for 15 mL of a K2Cr2O7 aqueous solution (50 mg L–1) after addition of 10 mg of compound 1 and further centrifugation to monitor the Cr2O7 2– concentration at different time intervals. (b) Langmuir isotherm to evaluate the maximum adsorption capacity with a correlation coefficient of 0.9838.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Plots of UV/vis spectra for 15 mL of a K2Cr2O7 aqueous solution (50 mg L-1) after addition of 10 mg of compound 1 and further centrifugation to monitor the Cr2O7 2- concentration at different time intervals. (b) Langmuir isotherm to evaluate the maximum adsorption capacity with a correlation coefficient of 0.9838.

cln_elements.content: (a) Room-temperature excitation (black) and emission (red) spectra of Eu3+@2. (b) Room-temperature excitation (black) and emission (green) spectra of Tb3+@2.

cln_elements.content: (a) Experimental (black) and calculated (red) luminescence decay plots for Eu3+@2 for a peak at 616 nm after excitation at 333 nm. (b) Experimental (black) and calculated (green) luminescence decay plots for Tb3+@2 for a peak at 582 nm after excitation at 337 nm.

metadata.title:
Two Novel Self-Catenated Metal–Organic Frameworks
with Large Accessible Channels Obtained by a Mixed-Ligand Strategy:
Adsorption of Dichromate and Ln3+ Postsynthetic Modification
